Manifest.Name: Windows Task Scheduler PS Job Monitoring - Windows Server 2008 and later

WriteAction.ScriptBody:
# Enables Task Scheduler History # # sets event log flag # # Version 1.0 - 01. July 2014 - initial - Raphael Burri - raburri@bluewin.ch
param ( [string]$scriptName = 'Custom.TaskScheduler2.Task.EnableTaskSchedulerHistory.ps1')
#region constvar #constants & variables $FLAG_KEY = "HKLM:\SOFTWARE\Microsoft\Windows\CurrentVersion\WINEVT\Channels\Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler/Operational" $FLAG_VALUE = "Enabled" #endregion
#region main $currentvalue = (Get-ItemProperty -Path $FLAG_KEY -Name $FLAG_VALUE -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Enabled
if ($currentvalue -eq $null) { Write-Host "WARNING: Task Scheduler History Event Log key does not exist." } elseif ($currentvalue -eq 1) { Write-Host "INFORMATION: Task Scheduler History is already enabled. No action required." } else { #enable history Set-ItemProperty -Path $FLAG_KEY -Name $FLAG_VALUE -Value 1 -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue #verify $currentvalue = (Get-ItemProperty -Path $FLAG_KEY -Name $FLAG_VALUE -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue).Enabled if ($currentvalue -eq 1) { Write-Host "SUCCESS: Task Scheduler History is now enabled." } else { Write-Host "WARNING: Failed to enable Task Scheduler History. The current user does not have write access to the system's registry. Make sure you run this task/recovery with a user account that has administrative access rights." } }
#endregion

# Custom.TaskScheduler2.Task.WorkflowTriggerEvent.ps1 # # Writes an entry to SCOM event log (with extra parameters) # # Parameters:
param ($scriptName = 'Custom.TaskScheduler2.Task.WorkflowTriggerEvent.ps1', $eventId = '1005', $waitTime = '300', $mpName = 'Custom.Windows.TaskScheduler.Windows2008.Monitoring', $mgName = 'none', $eventType = 'unknownType', $eventCount = '0', $timeStart = '', $timeEnd = '')
Function WriteEventLogEntry { param ([string]$EventSourceName, $EventId, [string]$EventSeverity, [string]$EventDescription, [string]$EventParameter1, [string]$EventParameter2, [string]$EventParameter3, [string]$EventParameter4, [string]$EventParameter5, [string]$EventParameter6, [string]$EventParameter7, [string]$EventParameter8 ) # using .NET objects as they allow event parameters $newEvent = new-object System.Diagnostics.Eventinstance($EventId, 0, [system.diagnostics.eventlogentrytype]::[string]$EventSeverity) [System.diagnostics.EventLog]::WriteEvent([string]$EventSourceName, $newEvent, $EventDescription, $EventParameter1, $EventParameter2, $EventParameter3, $EventParameter4, $EventParameter5, $EventParameter6, $EventParameter7, $EventParameter8)
}
WriteEventLogEntry -EventSourceName 'Health Service Script' -EventId $eventId -EventSeverity 'Information' -EventDescription 'Windows TaskScheduler MP Helper Event. This event is used to trigger Task Scheduler MP workflows. Management Pack: %4 Management Group: %5
EventType: %6 EventCount: %7
TimeWindowStart: %8 TimeWindowEnd: %9
' -EventParameter1 $ScriptName -EventParameter2 $waitTime -EventParameter3 $MPName -EventParameter4 $MGName -EventParameter5 $eventType -EventParameter6 $eventCount -EventParameter7 $timeStart -EventParameter8 $timeEnd

DisplayString.Name: PowerShell Job
DisplayString.Description: PSScheduledJob (introduced with PowerShell 3.0)

DisplayString.Name: Powershell Job (time scheduled)
DisplayString.Description: PSScheduledJob (introduced with PowerShell 3.0) - with a repetitive schedule

DisplayString.Name: WinD (internal)
DisplayString.Description: Flag to mark if Windows OS tasks were discovered on this computer. It will be used to configure monitor and rule workflows.

DisplayString.Name: Scheduled tasks with ShowMessage action group
DisplayString.Description: Since the normal return code of a ShowMessage action is '1', this group is the target for an override for the tasks' return code.

DisplayString.Name: Scheduler 2.0 Task Computer Group
DisplayString.Description: Contains computers on which Task Scheduler 2.x tasks were discovered (Windows 2008 - 2012 R2)

DisplayString.Name: Custom.TaskScheduler2.Task.GetTaskProperties.Discovery.DataSource
DisplayString.Description: Script Discovery DS

DisplayString.Name: Windows Task Scheduler 2.x General Trigger Task Discovery (Windows Server 2008 through 2012 R2)
Windows Task Scheduler 2.x Schedule Triggered Task Discovery (Windows Server 2008 through 2012 R2)
PowerShell Job General Trigger Job Discovery (Windows Server 2008 through 2012 R2)
PowerShell Job Schedule Triggered Job Discovery (Windows Server 2008 through 2012 R2)
Populate 'Scheduled tasks with ShowMessage action group'
DisplayString.Description: GroupCalc

DisplayString.Name: Populate 'Scheduler 2.0 Task Computer Group'
DisplayString.Description: GroupCalc

DisplayString.Name: Windows Task Scheduler and PS Job Monitoring - Windows Server 2008 / 2008 R2 / 2012 / 2012 R2 / 2016
DisplayString.Description: Discovers and monitors the health of Windows 2008 - 2016 server based scheduled tasks and PowerShell scheduled jobs.

DisplayString.Name: Last Result Successful Monitor - PSJob Error Count
PS Scheduled Job failed to complete successfully
Scheduled Task Monitoring compatibility
DisplayString.Description: The "Windows Task Scheduler and PS Job Monitoring" management pack uses PowerShell to discover and monitor scheduled tasks. If Powershell is not installed, the management pack will fail to discover tasks and jobs.

DisplayString.Name: Task Scheduler Monitoring is not possible
DisplayString.Description:
PowerShell is not installed on computer {0} or the installed version is not compatible with PowerShell 2.0.
In order to monitor scheduled tasks, install the appropriate PowerShell environment (>= Version 2.0).

DisplayString.Name: Scheduled Task's schedule expired
Scheduled Tasks History Enabled
DisplayString.Description: All Tasks History must be enabled or the Scheduled Task MP will not be able to monitor the scheduled tasks.

DisplayString.Name: Task Scheduler: All Tasks History is disabled
DisplayString.Description:
All Tasks History on computer '{0}' is disabled. The Scheduled Task Management Pack will not be able to monitor the tasks on this computer.
"Enable All Tasks History" on the Task Scheduler's action pane.

DisplayString.Name: Scheduled Task ran past next scheduled execution
Scheduled Task failed to complete successfully
Scheduled Task is/was running too long
Scheduled Task has no active triggers
Enable "All Tasks History"
DisplayString.Description: Enables Task Scheduler event log on Windows 2008 and later.

DisplayString.Name: Collect scheduled task job duration
DisplayString.Description: Writes the following performance counters: Windows Scheduled Tasks / Job Duration (min)

DisplayString.Name: Task Scheduler Action Observer Rule
DisplayString.Description: Consolidated rule that writes an event to the 'Operations Manager' event log after task scheduler actions have been observed in the Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler event log.

DisplayString.Name: Task Scheduler Configuration Change Observer Rule
DisplayString.Description: Consolidated rule that writes an event to the 'Operations Manager' event log after task scheduler configuration has changed. Looks for events in the Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler event log.

DisplayString.Name: Task Scheduler Evaluation Trigger Rule
DisplayString.Description: Consolidated rule that writes an event to the 'Operations Manager' event log every 4 hours. That event is used to trigger monitors and rules.

DisplayString.Name: Enable All Tasks History
DisplayString.Description: Enables Task Scheduler event log on Windows Server 2008 and later.

DisplayString.Name: Management Pack Alerts
DisplayString.Description: Alerts about the internal operations of the management pack. They are not related to the scheduled tasks themselfes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: PowerShell Scheduled Job Last Result Monitor.
The monitor checks the last result of a PowerShell Scheduled Job for error items (exceptions).
Any error observed is considered a warning condition for scheduled job with trigger(s).

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Use overrides to:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Allow a number of exceptions to be considered a healthy condition.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The PowerShell script called by the Scheduled Job threw exceptions.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Log onto the affected computer as the user that created the PowerShell Scheduled Job and run the following PowerShell command to get access to the job's last result:

maml:listItem.maml:para: gets the latest result object of a scheduled job, including the script code that ran.

maml:section.maml:para: This allows further investigating why the script did not complete sucessfully. Refer to the "Additional" section in case changes to the job are required.
and/or Re-run Scheduled Job
Disable or delete the PowerShell Scheduled Job

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: TechNet documentation regarding PSScheduledJob:
- Windows PowerShell Scheduled Job Cmdlets

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: PowerShell Version >= 2.0 is required for scheduled task and PowerShell scheduled job monitoring.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Download and install PowerShell 2.0 or later on this agent computer from www.microsoft.com

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows Scheduled Task Next Run Defined Monitor.
The monitor checks the next run time of a scheduled taks every minute.
'Never' is considered a warning condition for an enabled scheduled task.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Use overrides to:
- Disable the monitor

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The task's schedule has expired

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Reconfigure the Scheduled Task
Disable or delete the Scheduled Task

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows Scheduled Tasks History Enabled Monitor.
The monitor checks if logging to the 'Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler/Operational' event log is enabled.
Without logging enabled 'Windows Task Scheduler Monitoring MP' will not be able to properly monitor the scheduled tasks on this computer.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Open 'Task Scheduler' (taskschd.msc /s) and:
- 'Enable All Tasks History' from the action pane

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: Logging to 'Microsoft-Windows-TaskScheduler/Operational' is not enabled

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Enable logging

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Next scheduled execution skipped Monitor.
The monitor checks if a scheduled task's execution was skipped because it was still running at the time it should have been started.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Use overrides to:
- Disable the monitor

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The scheduled task is taking longer to complete than expected.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Reconfigure the scheduled task's schedule to accomodate for its execution duration.
Consider altering the task so that it terminates faster.

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: Monitor is based on Warning event 322 (Launch request ignored, instance already running) in the TaskScheduler log. It will return to green if:
- The task is executed normally (no 322 event during a run)
- The task is disabled

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Windows Scheduled Task Last Result Monitor.
The monitor checks the last result code (exit code) of a scheduled task.
Anything other than the following values is considered a warning condition for an enabled scheduled task.
- '1' (for tasks containing a popup action)
- '267009': currently running
- '267014': was terminated by user
- '-2147216609': instance of this task already running -> being taken care of by the separate monitor
- '-2147750687': task already running -> being taken care of by the separate monitor

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Use overrides to:

maml:listItem.maml:para: Alter the expected return code 'Expected Return Code (RegEx)'. Use a valid regular expression. E.g. ^(0|9|123)$

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The process called by the scheduled task failed
Authentication problems of the scheduled tasks user account

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Consult the event log of the affected machine and/or Run Scheduled Task
Disable or delete the Scheduled Task

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: msdn reference about task scheduler 2.0 constants:
- Task Scheduler Error and Success Constants
Note that the Operations Manager management pack displays the error codes as decimal values while the reference states hexadecimal.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: Long running task monitor.
The monitor checks if a scheduled task is taking too long to complete. This monitor is disabled by default.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Use overrides to:

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The task is taking longer to complete than expected.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: Consider optimizing the task so that it terminates faster

maml:section.maml:title: Additional
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor will detect long running tasks reliably as long as they are not started more often than every 15 minutes.

maml:section.maml:title: Summary
maml:section.maml:para: This monitor checks if a task has at least one trigger enabled. Tasks without any active triggers will never run unless started manually.

maml:section.maml:title: Configuration
maml:section.maml:para: Disable the monitor if not required. Do so using overrides.

maml:section.maml:title: Causes
maml:section.maml:para: The task does not have any triggers or all are disabled.

maml:section.maml:title: Resolutions
maml:section.maml:para: If you need the task running:
- Add or enable triggers
If you do not need the task running:
- Disable or delete the task
